title: Boris Johnson threatens to abandon Brexit deal Bill altogether in MPs battle
text:

Boris Johnson’s allies have threatened to pull his Brexit deal Bill altogether if his plans are scuppered or amended by MPs.

A No10 source told the BBC the PM is braced for the radical decision if MPs vote down his bid to get his plans through in three days tonight. A Cabinet minister also refused to rule out the ‘nuclear option’ if MPs amend the Bill beyond recognition.

The blatant bullying tactic against wavering MPs was unleashed as the EU Withdrawal Agreement Bill - which enacts the Brexit deal in UK law - begins rushed scrutiny and knife edge votes in the Commons in a desperate bid to leave by October 31.

A Downing Street source told the BBC: "If Parliament votes again for delay by voting down the programme motion, and the EU offers delay until 31 Jan, then we will pull the Bill.

"There will be no further business for Parliament and we'll move to an election before Christmas."

If Mr Johnson dropped the Bill he’d be unable to bring it back without proroguing Parliament or holding an election.

That would kill the deal he agreed with EU leaders stone dead because it could not pass into UK law. And it would leave Britain either facing a no-deal exit next Thursday or - if EU leaders allow it - another Brexit delay.

(Image: Leon Neal)

MPs will vote tonight on a 'programme motion' on whether to accept Boris Johnson's bid to push through all Commons stages of the Bill in three days.

One vote on a second referendum is due at 1am on Thursday - which Labour’s Thangam Debbonaire said would be a "security risk" for MPs and staff leaving in the early hours.

Asked what would happen if the PM loses the programme motion, a No10 spokesman said: "We would set out in due course.

"What we’re focused on first is winning support for a deal. If MPs do finally vote for a deal, the public will rightly expect them to get on with passing the legislation so we can leave on Oct 31”.

He added: “Voting down the programme motion has serious implications, it means legislation can drift on and on. That’s not in the interests of the UK or the EU. It’s time to get this done.”

(Image: Sky News)

Meanwhile No10 allies also claim the deal could be dropped if it's heavily amended.

Labour wants to try adding a UK-EU customs union to the deal - which would rip up the Tories’ attempt to stay out of EU rules and strike trade deals with the rest of the world.

Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick said Today: “We don’t want to compromise the integrity of the deal we’ve negotiated with the EU.”

Asked if that could mean pulling the whole thing, he said: “That will be a decision for the Prime Minister.

“But we’re not going to compromise on this deal because it’s a good deal, it delivers on the outcome of the referendum.

“And it’s the only deal that’s out there that both the EU and the UK consider a good one that can take the whole of Europe forwards.”

It comes after Downing Street dropped hints yesterday that the whole deal could be dropped if it is amended in a big way.

(Image: Getty Images)

The Prime Minister’s spokesman said: “The deal with the EU has just been agreed, it’s been done, it’s closed. The PM is focused on getting that deal through Parliament.”

He suggested an amended deal would then get snarled up at the EU end.

He said: “If essentially the legislation in the House of Commons steps too far from what was agreed in the original withdrawal agreement and political declaration that does bring into question ratification.”

A senior government source said: “This is the PM that quit the Cabinet over a customs union, I can’t see him standing for it now”.

But one minister suggested the PM would simply grin and bear it - and instead turn his focus to the future relationship.

Plus even if the Bill was amended for a Customs Union, there is highly likely to be an election before the future relationship deal is struck with EU.

That means a future Tory government could override a customs union amendment, because no parliament can bind the hands of a successor.
description: Dropping the EU Withdrawal Agreement Bill would be the nuclear option - and leave Boris Johnson unable to bring his deal back
